title: Micah Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Micah chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Micah Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Micah Chapter 3.

questions.question: Who does Micah 3:1 address as needing to know judgment?
options: Heads of Jacob and princes of Israel
The prophets and priests
The people of Jerusalem
The foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: Heads of Jacob and princes of Israel
questions.explanation: Micah 3:1 specifically addresses the heads of Jacob and princes of the house of Israel as those who should know judgment.

questions.question: According to Micah 3:2, what do the leaders hate and love?
options: Hate the good and love the evil
Hate the evil and love the good
Hate all people and love themselves
Hate the poor and love the rich
questions.correctAnswer: Hate the good and love the evil
questions.explanation: Micah 3:2 describes the leaders as those who hate the good and love the evil.

questions.question: What do the leaders do to the people as described in Micah 3:3?
options: They eat their flesh and flay their skin
They shelter and protect them
They teach them righteousness
They feed them with wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: They eat their flesh and flay their skin
questions.explanation: Micah 3:3 uses vivid imagery to describe the leaders as eating the flesh of the people and flaying their skin.

questions.question: According to Micah 3:4, what will happen when the people cry unto the LORD?
options: The LORD will hide His face and not hear
The LORD will answer immediately
The LORD will send a prophet
The LORD will bring peace
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will hide His face and not hear
questions.explanation: Micah 3:4 states that when the people cry unto the LORD, He will not hear them and will hide His face because of their evil deeds.

questions.question: Who do the prophets bite with their teeth and cry, 'Peace,' according to Micah 3:5?
options: The people of Israel
The heads of Jacob
The priests
The foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: The people of Israel
questions.explanation: Micah 3:5 describes prophets that make God's people err by biting with their teeth and crying, 'Peace.'

questions.question: What will happen to the seers and diviners as described in Micah 3:7?
options: They will be ashamed and cover their lips
They will receive great honor
They will prophesy clearly
They will be exalted by the people
questions.correctAnswer: They will be ashamed and cover their lips
questions.explanation: Micah 3:7 says seers will be ashamed and diviners confounded, covering their lips because there is no answer from God.

questions.question: In Micah 3:8, what fills the speaker with power and might?
options: The spirit of the LORD
The wisdom of the elders
The strength of the people
The law of Moses
questions.correctAnswer: The spirit of the LORD
questions.explanation: Micah 3:8 states the speaker is full of power by the spirit of the LORD, enabling him to declare transgressions and sins.

questions.question: Who does Micah 3:9 say abhor judgment and pervert equity?
options: Heads of Jacob and princes of Israel
Prophets and priests
The common people
Foreign rulers
questions.correctAnswer: Heads of Jacob and princes of Israel
questions.explanation: Micah 3:9 calls out the heads of Jacob and princes of Israel as those who abhor judgment and pervert equity.

questions.question: What do the leaders build up with blood and iniquity according to Micah 3:10?
options: Zion and Jerusalem
Egypt and Assyria
Babylon and Nineveh
Samaria and Damascus
questions.correctAnswer: Zion and Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Micah 3:10 states that the leaders build up Zion with blood and Jerusalem with iniquity.

questions.question: According to Micah 3:11, what do the heads, priests, and prophets do for reward or money?
options: Judge, teach, and divine
Pray, fast, and worship
Build, sow, and harvest
Feed, comfort, and heal
questions.correctAnswer: Judge, teach, and divine
questions.explanation: Micah 3:11 says the heads judge for reward, priests teach for hire, and prophets divine for money.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 3:6 says the sun will go down over the prophets and the day shall be dark over them.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Micah 3:6 clearly mentions that the sun will go down over the prophets and the day shall be dark over them.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 3:12 predicts that Jerusalem will become heaps because of the people's actions.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Micah 3:12 states that Jerusalem will become heaps, indicating destruction due to the people's sins.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 3:4 says the LORD will hear the people when they cry to Him.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Micah 3:4 actually says the LORD will not hear the people when they cry because of their evil deeds.

questions.question: Complete the verse from Micah 3:3: 'Who also eat the flesh of my people, and _____ their skin from off them;'
options: flay
cover
heal
feed
questions.correctAnswer: flay
questions.explanation: Micah 3:3 says they 'eat the flesh of my people, and flay their skin from off them.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Micah 3:11: 'The heads thereof judge for reward, and the priests thereof teach for _____, and the prophets thereof divine for money;'
options: hire
free
love
charity
questions.correctAnswer: hire
questions.explanation: Micah 3:11 states that priests teach for hire, indicating corrupt motives.

medium.title: Micah Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Micah Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer struggles with trusting leaders who seem unjust. Based on Micah 3:1-3, what biblical truth would you share about the qualities leaders should have?
options: Leaders should know judgment and hate evil, not exploit the people.
Leaders should seek personal gain and ignore the people's needs.
Leaders should prioritize their power over justice.
Leaders should remain silent and avoid involvement.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders should know judgment and hate evil, not exploit the people.
questions.explanation: Micah 3:1-3 calls leaders to know judgment and condemns those who love evil and harm God's people. This teaches that leaders must value justice and protect the vulnerable.

questions.question: How does Micah 3:4 teach us about the consequences of persistent disobedience and wrongdoing in leadership?
options: God will hide His face and not hear their cries.
God will immediately forgive without conditions.
God will bless their leadership without question.
God will strengthen them to continue ruling.
questions.correctAnswer: God will hide His face and not hear their cries.
questions.explanation: Micah 3:4 warns that when leaders behave ill, God will not hear their prayers and will hide His face, showing the serious consequences of unrepentant sin.

questions.question: What warning does Micah 3:5 give concerning false prophets and their impact on the community?
options: False prophets lead people astray by claiming peace while preparing for war.
False prophets always speak truth and lead to peace.
False prophets avoid conflict and seek reconciliation.
False prophets encourage the people to obey God's Word.
questions.correctAnswer: False prophets lead people astray by claiming peace while preparing for war.
questions.explanation: Micah 3:5 describes false prophets who say 'Peace' but bite like wolves and prepare war against those who do not give them what they want, showing the danger of deceitful leadership.

questions.question: A believer asks why God might seem silent during difficult times. How does Micah 3:6-7 explain this silence?
options: Because of the people's sin, God causes darkness and no divine answers.
God is testing their faith by withholding all communication.
God has forgotten His people temporarily.
God is always visible and answers every prayer immediately.
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the people's sin, God causes darkness and no divine answers.
questions.explanation: Micah 3:6-7 explains that due to the people's wrongdoing, there will be no visions or answers from God, symbolizing spiritual darkness as a consequence of sin.

questions.question: How does Micah 3:8 encourage believers to respond to sin and injustice in their community?
options: By being empowered by the Spirit to declare sin and call for repentance.
By ignoring sin and focusing only on personal matters.
By supporting unjust leaders for peace.
By avoiding judgment and confrontation.
questions.correctAnswer: By being empowered by the Spirit to declare sin and call for repentance.
questions.explanation: Micah 3:8 shows that through the Spirit of the LORD, one can have power and might to declare transgressions and call people to repentance, encouraging believers to confront sin.

questions.question: What does Micah 3:9-10 teach about integrity and justice in leadership?
options: Leaders should not pervert justice or build communities through bloodshed.
Leaders should seek personal reward regardless of justice.
Justice is optional for those in power.
Leaders should focus on wealth accumulation.
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders should not pervert justice or build communities through bloodshed.
questions.explanation: Micah 3:9-10 condemns leaders who abhor judgment and build Zion with blood, teaching that integrity and justice are essential for leadership.

questions.question: How does Micah 3:11 warn us about the dangers of corruption in religious leadership?
options: Religious leaders who judge and teach for money falsely trust God’s protection.
Religious leaders are always trustworthy regardless of motives.
Religion and money never mix, so this is not a concern.
Corruption in leadership has no impact on the community.
questions.correctAnswer: Religious leaders who judge and teach for money falsely trust God’s protection.
questions.explanation: Micah 3:11 criticizes leaders who serve for reward yet claim God is among them, showing the danger of hypocrisy and misplaced trust.

questions.question: Based on Micah 3:12, what practical lesson can we learn about the consequences of unrepentant sin in a community?
options: Unrepentant sin leads to destruction and desolation of the community.
Sin has no lasting effect on cities or people.
God will always protect cities regardless of sin.
Communities can ignore sin without consequence.
questions.correctAnswer: Unrepentant sin leads to destruction and desolation of the community.
questions.explanation: Micah 3:12 foretells Zion being plowed like a field because of sin, teaching that ongoing disobedience results in judgment and ruin.

questions.question: True or False: According to Micah 3:2-3, leaders who love evil and harm God's people will ultimately succeed without consequences.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Micah 3:2-3 describes leaders who love evil and harm God's people, and later verses (3:4, 3:12) show they face God's judgment and consequences.

questions.question: True or False: Micah 3:8 encourages believers to be silent about sin to maintain peace in the community.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Micah 3:8 states that the prophet is full of power to declare transgression and sin, encouraging speaking out rather than silence.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Micah 3:11 says, "The heads thereof judge for _____, and the priests thereof teach for hire, and the prophets thereof divine for money."
options: reward
free
justice
mercy
questions.correctAnswer: reward
questions.explanation: Micah 3:11 describes corrupt leaders who judge for reward, showing how greed corrupts justice and teaching.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with forgiveness towards leaders who have wronged them. How does Micah 3:9-11 guide our understanding of justice and grace in such situations?
options: Recognize the sin and perversion of justice but trust God’s ultimate judgment.
Ignore sin and pretend all is well to keep peace.
Seek revenge against unjust leaders immediately.
Accept all wrongdoing as normal and do nothing.
questions.correctAnswer: Recognize the sin and perversion of justice but trust God’s ultimate judgment.
questions.explanation: Micah 3:9-11 highlights corruption but points to God’s authority over justice, encouraging believers to trust God rather than take matters into their own hands.

questions.question: What does Micah 3:6-7 teach about spiritual discernment and dependence on God during difficult times?
options: Without God’s answer, we must humbly wait and seek Him earnestly.
If God is silent, we should rely solely on human wisdom.
Spiritual discernment is unnecessary during trials.
We should stop praying if answers do not come immediately.
questions.correctAnswer: Without God’s answer, we must humbly wait and seek Him earnestly.
questions.explanation: Micah 3:6-7 shows that when God’s answer is absent, seers are ashamed, urging believers to humbly seek God despite silence.

questions.question: Based on Micah 3:1, why is it important for leaders and believers alike to understand and practice judgment and righteousness?
options: Because knowing judgment is their responsibility to promote justice.
Because judgment is only for priests, not leaders.
Because people will ignore righteous judgment anyway.
Because judgment should be avoided to keep peace.
questions.correctAnswer: Because knowing judgment is their responsibility to promote justice.
questions.explanation: Micah 3:1 emphasizes that leaders are meant to know judgment, highlighting their duty to uphold justice and righteousness.

questions.question: How does Micah 3:10 challenge believers involved in community building and stewardship?
options: To build their communities on righteousness, not through injustice or violence.
To focus only on physical construction regardless of ethics.
To prioritize wealth over justice in community development.
To ignore the spiritual condition of the community.
questions.correctAnswer: To build their communities on righteousness, not through injustice or violence.
questions.explanation: Micah 3:10 condemns building Zion with blood and Jerusalem with iniquity, urging believers to pursue justice in stewardship.

hard.title: Micah Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Micah Chapter 3.

questions.question: In Micah 3:1, who is addressed as responsible to know judgment?
options: Heads of Jacob and princes of Israel
The prophets and priests
The common people
Foreign nations
questions.correctAnswer: Heads of Jacob and princes of Israel
questions.explanation: Micah 3:1 directly addresses the heads of Jacob and princes of the house of Israel as those who should know judgment.

questions.question: What metaphor does Micah 3:2 use to describe those who hate the good and love the evil?
options: They pluck off their skin and flesh from their bones
They build walls of stone around their hearts
They are like blind watchmen
They sow seeds on rocky ground
questions.correctAnswer: They pluck off their skin and flesh from their bones
questions.explanation: The verse uses vivid imagery of plucking skin and flesh to symbolize violent oppression and cruelty.

questions.question: According to Micah 3:3, the leaders are compared to which of the following in their treatment of God's people?
options: Chopping bones for a pot, like flesh in a caldron
Shepherds guiding their flock
Builders strengthening the walls
Kings holding a scepter of justice
questions.correctAnswer: Chopping bones for a pot, like flesh in a caldron
questions.explanation: The verse uses the gruesome imagery of chopping bones and flesh as if preparing food to illustrate their brutal exploitation.

questions.question: What consequence is described in Micah 3:4 for those who behave ill in their doings?
options: The LORD will hide His face and not hear their cries
They will be exalted in the land
They will receive wealth and honor
Their names will be remembered forever
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will hide His face and not hear their cries
questions.explanation: Micah 3:4 states that the LORD will hide His face and not hear them because of their evil behavior.

questions.question: What is the behavior of the false prophets described in Micah 3:5?
options: They bite with their teeth and cry, Peace; and prepare war against those who do not feed them
They preach righteousness and justice
They fast and pray earnestly
They build altars to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: They bite with their teeth and cry, Peace; and prepare war against those who do not feed them
questions.explanation: Micah 3:5 describes false prophets as deceitful and aggressive toward those who oppose them.

questions.question: True or False: According to Micah 3:6, the prophets will continue to have clear visions and divine accurately.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Micah 3:6 states that night and darkness will come upon the prophets, meaning they will lack visions and fail to divine.

questions.question: What reaction will the seers have when there is no answer from God, as described in Micah 3:7?
options: They will be ashamed and cover their lips
They will rejoice and sing
They will prophesy louder
They will write new laws
questions.correctAnswer: They will be ashamed and cover their lips
questions.explanation: Micah 3:7 explains that seers will be ashamed and silent because God gives no answer.

questions.question: In Micah 3:8, the prophet declares he is filled with power by what means?
options: The spirit of the LORD
The wisdom of the elders
The strength of his army
The riches of the temple
questions.correctAnswer: The spirit of the LORD
questions.explanation: Micah 3:8 clearly states the prophet is empowered by the spirit of the LORD to declare judgment.

questions.question: Micah 3:9 criticizes the leaders for what specific corruption?
options: Abhorring judgment and perverting equity
Enforcing strict justice
Building the temple faithfully
Leading the people in righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: Abhorring judgment and perverting equity
questions.explanation: The verse condemns leaders for rejecting fair judgment and twisting justice.

questions.question: How do the leaders build Zion and Jerusalem according to Micah 3:10?
options: With blood and iniquity
With wisdom and peace
With gold and silver
With prayers and fasting
questions.correctAnswer: With blood and iniquity
questions.explanation: Micah 3:10 accuses leaders of building Zion and Jerusalem through violence and sin.

questions.question: What corrupt practices are associated with heads, priests, and prophets in Micah 3:11?
options: Judging for reward, teaching for hire, and divining for money
Leading with integrity and truth
Ignoring the people’s pleas
Destroying idols and false gods
questions.correctAnswer: Judging for reward, teaching for hire, and divining for money
questions.explanation: The verse describes these leaders as corrupt, motivated by bribes and money.

questions.question: Despite their corruption, what false confidence do the leaders have according to Micah 3:11?
options: They lean upon the LORD and say no evil can come upon us
They fear the LORD and repent
They seek forgiveness from the people
They prepare for exile
questions.correctAnswer: They lean upon the LORD and say no evil can come upon us
questions.explanation: This verse highlights their hypocrisy in trusting God while practicing injustice.

questions.question: What is the prophetic judgment pronounced on Zion and Jerusalem in Micah 3:12?
options: Zion will be plowed as a field and Jerusalem become heaps
Zion will be exalted and Jerusalem rebuilt
Zion will be fortified and Jerusalem expanded
Zion will be cleansed of sin and Jerusalem purified
questions.correctAnswer: Zion will be plowed as a field and Jerusalem become heaps
questions.explanation: Micah 3:12 predicts destruction and desolation as punishment for corruption.

questions.question: Which literary device is prominently used in Micah 3:2-3 to describe the leaders’ cruelty?
options: Graphic imagery and metaphor
Parable and allegory
Chiasm and parallelism
Hyperbole and simile
questions.correctAnswer: Graphic imagery and metaphor
questions.explanation: The vivid description of skinning and chopping flesh serves as metaphorical graphic imagery.

questions.question: How does the theme of false prophecy in Micah 3:5-7 relate to New Testament warnings about false teachers?
options: Both warn against deceitful leaders who mislead for gain
Both affirm that all prophets are trustworthy
Both encourage blind faith without questioning
Both promote peace at any cost
questions.correctAnswer: Both warn against deceitful leaders who mislead for gain
questions.explanation: Micah 3 condemns false prophets for misleading people, a theme echoed in New Testament epistles.

theological.title: Micah Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Micah Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Micah 3:1, what responsibility do the heads of Jacob and princes of Israel have?
options: To know judgment
To lead in battle
To multiply wealth
To build temples
questions.correctAnswer: To know judgment
questions.explanation: Micah 3:1 explicitly says it is for the leaders to know judgment, emphasizing their role in administering justice, consistent with biblical calls for righteous leadership (cf. Deut 16:18; Isa 1:23; Ezek 22:26; James 3:1).

questions.question: What behavior is attributed to the leaders in Micah 3:2?
options: They hate the good and love the evil
They seek peace and love justice
They honor God and care for the poor
They teach the law faithfully
questions.correctAnswer: They hate the good and love the evil
questions.explanation: Micah 3:2 condemns the leaders for hating what is good and loving what is evil, illustrating their moral corruption, which contrasts with biblical ideals of righteous leadership (cf. Prov 3:7; Isa 5:20; Romans 12:9; Titus 1:8).

questions.question: In Micah 3:3, how are the leaders described in their treatment of God's people?
options: Like those who eat their flesh and break their bones
Like shepherds who protect their sheep
Like builders who strengthen the walls
Like watchmen who warn of danger
questions.correctAnswer: Like those who eat their flesh and break their bones
questions.explanation: Micah 3:3 uses graphic imagery of leaders who consume and destroy their people, symbolizing extreme exploitation and violence, echoing themes of oppression found in other scriptures (cf. Ezek 34:2-4; Jer 22:3; Isa 10:1-2; James 5:4).

questions.question: What is God's response when the leaders cry unto Him, according to Micah 3:4?
options: He will not hear them and will hide His face
He will answer with mercy and forgiveness
He will send angels to protect them
He will grant them peace and prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: He will not hear them and will hide His face
questions.explanation: Micah 3:4 states that God will hide His face and not hear their cries because of their evil deeds, demonstrating divine judgment and God's holiness (cf. Isa 59:2; Ps 66:18; Hos 5:15; Heb 10:26-27).

questions.question: According to Micah 3:5, what do the false prophets do to God's people?
options: Make them err and cry 'Peace' while preparing for war
Lead them faithfully in truth and justice
Teach the law and call for repentance
Encourage humility and trust in God
questions.correctAnswer: Make them err and cry 'Peace' while preparing for war
questions.explanation: Micah 3:5 condemns false prophets who deceive the people by proclaiming peace falsely, while secretly inciting conflict, reflecting warnings against deceit in prophecy (cf. Jer 6:14; Ezek 13:10-16; Matt 7:15; 2 Pet 2:1).

questions.question: What consequence is given in Micah 3:6 for the prophets who mislead the people?
options: They will have no vision and the day will be dark over them
They will be exalted and praised
They will receive a crown of righteousness
They will lead many to salvation
questions.correctAnswer: They will have no vision and the day will be dark over them
questions.explanation: Micah 3:6 pronounces judgment on false prophets with darkness and lack of divine revelation, highlighting God's withdrawal of guidance from those who corrupt His word (cf. Isa 8:20; Ezek 12:22; Amos 8:11; 1 Cor 14:8).

questions.question: What will happen to the seers and diviners as stated in Micah 3:7?
options: They will be ashamed and cover their lips for there is no answer from God
They will prophesy boldly and without fear
They will be granted visions and dreams
They will guide the people to righteousness
questions.correctAnswer: They will be ashamed and cover their lips for there is no answer from God
questions.explanation: Micah 3:7 describes the shame of false seers and diviners who cannot provide answers because God has withdrawn His revelation, consistent with biblical themes of divine silence toward the unfaithful (cf. Jer 23:16; Ezek 13:6; Hab 2:1; 1 Cor 14:32).

questions.question: In Micah 3:8, by whose spirit is the prophet empowered to declare transgressions?
options: The Spirit of the LORD
The spirit of the people
The spirit of the prophets
The spirit of the heavens
questions.correctAnswer: The Spirit of the LORD
questions.explanation: Micah 3:8 confirms the prophet's empowerment by the Spirit of the LORD to declare sin and judgment, highlighting divine inspiration of prophecy (cf. Num 11:29; Isa 61:1; Acts 2:17; 1 Pet 1:11).

questions.question: What sin do the heads of Jacob and princes of Israel commit, as described in Micah 3:9?
options: They abhor judgment and pervert all equity
They faithfully uphold the law and justice
They lead the people in worship and prayer
They care for widows and orphans
questions.correctAnswer: They abhor judgment and pervert all equity
questions.explanation: Micah 3:9 accuses leaders of rejecting justice and twisting fairness, which contradicts God's demands for righteous governance (cf. Isa 10:1; Prov 17:15; Amos 5:7; Luke 11:42).

questions.question: How do the leaders build Zion and Jerusalem according to Micah 3:10?
options: With blood and iniquity
With peace and righteousness
With wisdom and understanding
With prayer and fasting
questions.correctAnswer: With blood and iniquity
questions.explanation: Micah 3:10 states that Zion and Jerusalem are built up through violence and sin, reflecting the consequences of corrupt leadership (cf. Psalm 106:38; Jer 22:3; Ezek 22:2; Heb 11:4).

questions.question: According to Micah 3:11, what corrupt practices are the heads, priests, and prophets guilty of?
options: Judging for reward, teaching for hire, and divining for money
Serving selflessly and teaching truth
Prophesying by the Spirit and judging righteously
Leading worship and caring for the needy
questions.correctAnswer: Judging for reward, teaching for hire, and divining for money
questions.explanation: Micah 3:11 condemns leaders for corruption and greed, perverting justice and prophecy for personal gain, a violation of God's commands (cf. Ezek 22:12; Amos 8:6; Micah 6:11; 1 Cor 9:14).

questions.question: What false confidence do the leaders express in Micah 3:11 despite their corruption?
options: They say, 'Is not the LORD among us? None evil can come upon us.'
They confess their sins and seek mercy
They pray for guidance and strength
They trust in God's judgment against the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: They say, 'Is not the LORD among us? None evil can come upon us.'
questions.explanation: Despite their wickedness, leaders falsely trust God's presence as a shield, which God condemns as presumptuous (cf. Jer 7:4; Hosea 5:5; Luke 12:45-46; 1 Cor 10:12).

questions.question: What judgment does Micah 3:12 pronounce on Zion and Jerusalem?
options: Zion will be plowed as a field and Jerusalem become heaps
Zion will be exalted and Jerusalem rebuilt
Zion will be a refuge and Jerusalem a city of peace
Zion will prosper and Jerusalem flourish
questions.correctAnswer: Zion will be plowed as a field and Jerusalem become heaps
questions.explanation: Micah 3:12 foretells destruction and desolation as judgment for sin, consistent with prophetic warnings of exile and ruin (cf. Jer 26:18; Ezek 6:6; Zeph 3:6; Luke 19:43-44).

questions.question: How does Micah 3:8 depict the prophet’s role in relation to Israel’s sin?
options: To declare transgression and sin with power and judgment
To conceal the people's sins and avoid confrontation
To encourage sin for political gain
To ignore Israel's sin and focus on prosperity
questions.correctAnswer: To declare transgression and sin with power and judgment
questions.explanation: Micah 3:8 emphasizes the prophet’s divinely empowered role to expose sin and call for repentance, a theme echoed in prophetic ministry throughout Scripture (cf. Isa 6:8-10; Jer 1:17; Ezek 3:17; Acts 7:51).

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Micah 3:3 to describe the cruelty of the leaders?
options: Chopping them in pieces as for the pot
Building walls of stone
Shepherding like a caring flock
Planting vineyards for harvest
questions.correctAnswer: Chopping them in pieces as for the pot
questions.explanation: Micah 3:3 depicts leaders' brutal treatment as chopping people like meat for cooking, illustrating violent oppression, consistent with imagery of destruction in prophetic literature (cf. Ezek 22:2; Isa 9:20; Psalm 35:8; Luke 13:34).
